29 
[paragraph].63. The second kind of tentacle is homologous with the Prehensile organs of the <u>Diphydae & Physophoridae<\u> with 
the peculiar clavate processes of <u>Plumularia<\u> and so far 
as I can judge from descriptions of their structure with the 
tentacles of <u>Hydra<\u> 
all the organs here mentioned commence their development 
as bud-like processes of the two primary membranes - elongating 
and attaining the forms peculiar to their perfect state as 
they grow older - The tentacles of the medusae are usually 
developed (most <u>Monostomatae<\u>) from the circular vessel of the disc - sometimes (Phacellophora) from the diverging canals 
sometimes finally from the neck of the stomach (Lymnorea, 
Javonia) - the Prehensile organs of the Physophoridae also 
have considerable variety in position - In Porpita, Velella, Angela(?) 
they are developed from the margin of the float - In Physophora 
& many others from the base or the pedicle of the stomach - The peculiar clavate organs of Plumularia are developed from the common 
tube independently of the stomach 
[paragraph].64. The adult forms of these organs have all the same structure 
being composed of two membranes - with a vast number of 
thread cells of larger or smaller size seated in the substance 
of the outer membrane or between the inner and the outer - 
[paragraph]. 65. The "clavate organs" of Plumularia deserve especial notice 
as I am not aware that they have been hitherto described 
and as they exemplify in a very beautiful manner the 
5.
